item.title: [LOG4J2-1402] Exception when using log4j2.properties and logger with dot
item.description:
After upgrading log4j2 from 2.5 to 2.6 I get the following exception:

Exception in thread "main" org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.ConfigurationException: No name attribute provided for Logger org
at org.apache.logging.log4j.core.config.properties.PropertiesConfigurationBuilder.createLogger(PropertiesConfigurationBuilder.java:215)

The parameter "key" has the value "org" and the parameter properties has the value 

{activiti.engine.impl.level=info, activiti.engine.impl.name=org.activiti.engine.impl}

The log4j2.properties in use:

# Root logger option
rootLogger.level = info
rootLogger.appenderRefs = stdout
rootLogger.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

# Redirect log messages to console
appenders = stdout
appender.stdout.type = Console
appender.stdout.name = STDOUT
appender.stdout.layout.type = PatternLayout
appender.stdout.layout.pattern = %d %-5p [%t] %c - %m%n

Sadly I have not been able to reproduce the issue in a simple standalone application.
item.summary: Exception when using log4j2.properties and logger with dot

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
Hm, the root logger name is the empty string, so it sounds like we need a special case for that.

"I tried using a simple log4j2.xml instead, but that does not seem to help"

What do you mean? You use an XML config file and you get the same exception? That does not seem possible. Or is the config not doing what you expect.

Yes, you are correct. The exception does not occur when using a log4j2.xml file. I guess I had both files in the classpath before. Sorry. I will correct the issue description to avoid causing further confusion. Sorry again.
We do have a special case. We have a createLogger method and a createRootLogger method. We need to determine why createLogger is being called instead of createRootLogger.

I'm a bit confused. The error means that it found something like:

logger.org.level = info
logger.org.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

but didn't find

logger.org.name = org.apache

But the sample above only shows the rootLogger, which doesn't even use the createLogger method.

Based on what you saw (presumably while debugging) I am guessing the actual file contains

logger.org.activiti.engine.impl.level=info
logger.org.activiti.engine.impl.name=org.activiti.engine.impl

I believe this is due to the "enhancement" that was added to no longer require declaring the individual loggers as

loggers = org.activiti.engine.impl

The code now only allows the logger identifier to be a single "word" without any periods and so breaks configurations such as the above. This is a break in compatibility and needs to be fixed asap by still honoring the list of logger identifiers if it is present.

Those names are identifiers, not the logger name. For example:

logger.foo.name = org.apache.commons
logger.foo.level = warn

I don't even know if log4j 1.x supports complicated name identifiers like you're describing.

Our properties file support had no relationship to 1.x. The original code that I wrote and was delivered in 2.5 supported identifiers like what I showed above. We need to restore that.

I will modify log4j-rolling.properties so that it represents this case so it will fail and we can fix it.
It supported it, but there were no tests to show that it was expected behavior. I didn't know that would be a regression, sorry.
I guess the way forward would to make the "loggers" (and the others) property optional in case you want to use complex names like that.
Yes, that is what I would do.
This has been fixed in master. Please verify and close.

You are correct, there were multiple log4j2.properties files on the class path. Actually used was this one:

# Root logger option
rootLogger.level = debug
rootLogger.appenderRefs = stdout
rootLogger.appenderRef.stdout.ref = STDOUT

# Redirect log messages to console
appenders = stdout
appender.stdout.type = Console
appender.stdout.name = STDOUT
appender.stdout.layout.type = PatternLayout
appender.stdout.layout.pattern = %d %-5p [%t] %c - %m%n

loggers = org.activiti.engine.impl, spring, activiti.spring, ibatis, hikari, jsmpp

logger.org.activiti.engine.impl.name = org.activiti.engine.impl
logger.org.activiti.engine.impl.level = info
logger.spring.name = org.springframework
logger.spring.level = info
logger.activiti.spring.name = org.activiti.spring
logger.activiti.spring.level = info
logger.ibatis.name = org.apache.ibatis
logger.ibatis.level = info
logger.hikari.name = com.zaxxer.hikari
logger.hikari.level = info
logger.jsmpp.name = org.jsmpp
logger.jsmpp.level = info

I'm very sorry for posting the wrong file and confusing everybody.

Thanks you very much.

Sorry again for supplying wrong information.

Is there a maven repository I can use to retrieve the current snapshots (I do not have an environment to build log4j2 from source)?
Apache snapshots repository: https://repository.apache.org/content/groups/snapshots-group/ (version is 2.6.1-SNAPSHOT)
Did you deploy it? Our Jenkins build doesn't deploy the SNAPSHOTs. It probably should.

It looks like it's being deployed, though. I thought that was from Jenkins. Considering the test jenkins slaves would fail due to the inability to upload to the snapshots repository, I kinda assumed it was being deployed.
My mistake. The build does mvn clean install but there is a post build step to deploy to Nexus.
I was able to verify that the issue is solved in 2.6.1-SNAPHOT. Thanks!
